pli-tv-pvr4:1.8.eng: How many kinds of originations of offenses?

pli-tv-pvr4:1.13.eng: How many kinds of legal issues?

pli-tv-pvr4:1.14.eng: How many principles for settling them?

pli-tv-pvr4:2.1.eng: There are five kinds of offenses.

pli-tv-pvr4:2.2.eng: There are five classes of offenses.

pli-tv-pvr4:2.3.eng: There are five grounds of training.

pli-tv-pvr4:2.4.eng: There are seven kinds of offenses.

pli-tv-pvr4:2.5.eng: There are seven classes of offenses.

pli-tv-pvr4:2.6.eng: There are seven grounds of training.

pli-tv-pvr4:2.7.eng: There are six kinds of disrespect.

pli-tv-pvr4:2.8.eng: There are six kinds of respect.

pli-tv-pvr4:2.9.eng: There are six grounds of training.

pli-tv-pvr4:2.10.eng: There are four kinds of failure.

pli-tv-pvr4:2.11.eng: There are six kinds of originations of offenses.

pli-tv-pvr4:2.12.eng: There are six roots of disputes.

pli-tv-pvr4:2.13.eng: There are six roots of accusations.

pli-tv-pvr4:2.14.eng: There are six aspects of friendliness.

pli-tv-pvr4:2.15.eng: There are eighteen grounds for schism.

pli-tv-pvr4:2.16.eng: There are four kinds of legal issues.

pli-tv-pvr4:2.17.eng: There are seven principles for settling them.

pli-tv-pvr4:3.1.eng: What are the five kinds of offenses?

pli-tv-pvr4:3.2.eng: Offenses entailing expulsion, offenses entailing suspension, offenses entailing confession, offenses entailing acknowledgment, offenses of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-pvr4:4.1.eng: What are the five classes of offenses?

pli-tv-pvr4:4.2.eng: The class of offenses entailing expulsion, the class of offenses entailing suspension, the class of offenses entailing confession, the class of offenses entailing acknowledgment, the class of offenses of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-pvr4:5.1.eng: What are the five grounds of training?

pli-tv-pvr4:5.2.pli: Pañcahi āpattikkhandhehi ārati virati paṭivirati veramaṇī akiriyā akaraṇaṃ anajjhāpatti velāanatikkamo setughāto—
pli-tv-pvr4:5.2.eng: The refraining from, the keeping away from, the desisting from, the abstaining from, the non-doing of, the non-performing of, the non-committing of, the non-transgressing the boundary of, the incapability with respect to the five classes of offenses.

pli-tv-pvr4:6.1.eng: What are the seven kinds of offenses?

pli-tv-pvr4:6.2.pli: Pārājikāpatti, saṅghādisesāpatti, thullaccayāpatti, pācittiyāpatti, pāṭidesanīyāpatti, dukkaṭāpatti, dubbhāsitāpatti—
pli-tv-pvr4:6.2.eng: Offenses entailing expulsion, offenses entailing suspension, serious offenses, offenses entailing confession, offenses entailing acknowledgment, offenses of wrong conduct, offenses of wrong speech.

pli-tv-pvr4:7.1.eng: What are the seven classes of offenses?

pli-tv-pvr4:7.2.pli: Pārājikāpattikkhandho, saṅghādisesāpattikkhandho, thullaccayāpattikkhandho, pācittiyāpattikkhandho, pāṭidesanīyāpattikkhandho, dukkaṭāpattikkhandho, dubbhāsitāpattikkhandho—
pli-tv-pvr4:7.2.eng: The class of offenses entailing expulsion, the class of offenses entailing suspension, the class of serious offenses, the class of offenses entailing confession, the class of offenses entailing acknowledgment, the class of offenses of wrong conduct, the class of offenses of wrong speech.

pli-tv-pvr4:8.1.eng: What are the seven grounds of training?

pli-tv-pvr4:8.2.pli: Sattahi āpattikkhandhehi ārati virati paṭivirati veramaṇī akiriyā akaraṇaṃ anajjhāpatti velāanatikkamo setughāto—
pli-tv-pvr4:8.2.eng: The refraining from, the keeping away from, the desisting from, the abstaining from, the non-doing of, the non-performing of, the non-committing of, the non-transgressing the boundary of, the incapability with respect to the seven classes of offenses.

pli-tv-pvr4:9.1.eng: What are the six kinds of disrespect?

pli-tv-pvr4:9.2.pli: Buddhe agāravo, dhamme agāravo, saṅghe agāravo, sikkhāya agāravo, appamāde agāravo, paṭisandhāre agāravo—
pli-tv-pvr4:9.2.eng: Disrespect for the Buddha, disrespect for the Teaching, disrespect for the Sangha, disrespect for the training, disrespect for heedfulness, disrespect for hospitality.

pli-tv-pvr4:10.1.eng: What are the six kinds of respect?

pli-tv-pvr4:10.2.pli: Buddhe gāravo, dhamme gāravo, saṅghe gāravo, sikkhāya gāravo, appamāde gāravo, paṭisandhāre gāravo—
pli-tv-pvr4:10.2.eng: Respect for the Buddha, respect for the Teaching, respect for the Sangha, respect for the training, respect for heedfulness, respect for hospitality.

pli-tv-pvr4:11.1.eng: What are the six grounds of training?

pli-tv-pvr4:11.2.pli: Chahi agāravehi ārati virati paṭivirati veramaṇī akiriyā akaraṇaṃ anajjhāpatti velāanatikkamo setughāto—
pli-tv-pvr4:11.2.eng: The refraining from, the keeping away from, the desisting from, the abstaining from, the non-doing of, the non-performing of, the non-committing of, the non-transgressing the boundary of, the incapability with respect to the six kinds of disrespect.

pli-tv-pvr4:12.1.eng: What are four kinds of failure?

pli-tv-pvr4:12.2.eng: Failure in morality, failure in conduct, failure in view, failure in livelihood.

pli-tv-pvr4:13.1.eng: What are the six kinds of originations of offenses?

pli-tv-pvr4:13.2.pli: Atthāpatti kāyato samuṭṭhāti, na vācato na cittato;
pli-tv-pvr4:13.2.eng: There are offenses that originate from body, but not from speech or mind;

pli-tv-pvr4:13.3.pli: atthāpatti vācato samuṭṭhāti, na kāyato na cittato;
pli-tv-pvr4:13.3.eng: there are offenses that originate from speech, but not from body or mind;

pli-tv-pvr4:13.4.pli: atthāpatti kāyato ca vācato ca samuṭṭhāti, na cittato;
pli-tv-pvr4:13.4.eng: there are offenses that originate from body and speech, but not from mind;

pli-tv-pvr4:13.5.pli: atthāpatti kāyato ca cittato ca samuṭṭhāti, na vācato;
pli-tv-pvr4:13.5.eng: there are offenses that originate from body and mind, but not from speech;

pli-tv-pvr4:13.6.pli: atthāpatti vācato ca cittato ca samuṭṭhāti, na kāyato;
pli-tv-pvr4:13.6.eng: there are offenses that originate from speech and mind, but not from body;

pli-tv-pvr4:13.7.pli: atthāpatti kāyato ca vācato ca cittato ca samuṭṭhāti—
pli-tv-pvr4:13.7.eng: there are offenses that originate from body, speech, and mind.

pli-tv-pvr4:14.1.eng: What are the six roots of disputes?

pli-tv-pvr4:14.2.eng: (1) It may be that a monk is angry and resentful.

pli-tv-pvr4:14.3.pli: Yo so bhikkhu kodhano hoti upanāhī so sattharipi agāravo viharati appatisso, dhammepi agāravo viharati appatisso, saṅghepi agāravo viharati appatisso, sikkhāyapi na paripūrakārī hoti.
pli-tv-pvr4:14.3.eng: One who is angry and resentful is disrespectful and undeferential toward the Teacher, the Teaching, and the Sangha, and he doesn’t fulfill the training.

pli-tv-pvr4:14.4.pli: Yo so bhikkhu satthari agāravo viharati appatisso, dhamme …pe…

pli-tv-pvr4:14.6.pli: sikkhāya na paripūrakārī, so saṅghe vivādaṃ janeti.

pli-tv-pvr4:14.7.pli: Yo hoti vivādo bahujanāhitāya bahujanāsukhāya bahuno janassa anatthāya ahitāya dukkhāya devamanussānaṃ.
pli-tv-pvr4:14.7.eng: Disputes are unbeneficial and a cause of unhappiness for humanity; they are harmful, detrimental, and a cause of suffering for gods and humans.

pli-tv-pvr4:14.8.pli: Evarūpañce tumhe vivādamūlaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā samanupasseyyātha tatra tumhe tasseva pāpakassa vivādamūlassa pahānāya vāyameyyātha.
pli-tv-pvr4:14.8.eng: When you see such a root of disputes either in yourself or in others, you should make an effort to get rid of it.

pli-tv-pvr4:14.9.pli: Evarūpañce tumhe vivādamūlaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā na samanupasseyyātha tatra tumhe tasseva pāpakassa vivādamūlassa āyatiṃ anavassavāya paṭipajjeyyātha.
pli-tv-pvr4:14.9.eng: If you don’t see such a root either in yourself or in others, you should practice so that it has no future effect.

pli-tv-pvr4:14.10.eng: In this way that bad root of disputes is abandoned.

pli-tv-pvr4:14.11.pli: Evametassa pāpakassa vivādamūlassa āyatiṃ anavassavo hoti.
pli-tv-pvr4:14.11.eng: In this way that bad root of disputes has no future effect.

pli-tv-pvr4:15.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ bhikkhu makkhī hoti paḷāsī …pe…
pli-tv-pvr4:15.1.eng: (2) Or it may be that a monk is denigrating and domineering,

pli-tv-pvr4:15.2.pli: issukī hoti maccharī, saṭho hoti māyāvī, pāpiccho hoti micchādiṭṭhi, sandiṭṭhiparāmāsī hoti ādhānaggāhī duppaṭinissaggī.
pli-tv-pvr4:15.2.eng: (3) envious and stingy, (4) treacherous and deceitful, (5) one who has bad desires and wrong views, or (6) one who obstinately grasps his own views and only gives them up with difficulty.

pli-tv-pvr4:15.3.pli: Yo so bhikkhu sandiṭṭhiparāmāsī hoti ādhānaggāhī duppaṭinissaggī so sattharipi agāravo viharati appatisso, dhammepi agāravo viharati appatisso, saṅghepi agāravo viharati appatisso, sikkhāyapi na paripūrakārī hoti.
pli-tv-pvr4:15.3.eng: Any of these is disrespectful and undeferential toward the Teacher, the Teaching, and the Sangha, and he doesn’t fulfill the training.

pli-tv-pvr4:15.4.pli: Yo so bhikkhu satthari agāravo viharati appatisso dhamme …pe…

pli-tv-pvr4:15.6.pli: sikkhāya na paripūrakārī, so saṅghe vivādaṃ janeti.

pli-tv-pvr4:15.7.pli: Yo so hoti vivādo bahujanāhitāya bahujanāsukhāya bahuno janassa anatthāya ahitāya dukkhāya devamanussānaṃ.
pli-tv-pvr4:15.7.eng: Disputes are unbeneficial and a cause of unhappiness for humanity; they are harmful, detrimental, and a cause of suffering for gods and humans.

pli-tv-pvr4:15.8.pli: Evarūpañce tumhe vivādamūlaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā samanupasseyyātha tatra tumhe tasseva pāpakassa vivādamūlassa pahānāya vāyameyyātha.
pli-tv-pvr4:15.8.eng: When you see such a root of disputes either in yourself or in others, you should make an effort to get rid of it.

pli-tv-pvr4:15.9.pli: Evarūpañce tumhe vivādamūlaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā na samanupasseyyātha tatra tumhe tasseva pāpakassa vivādamūlassa āyatiṃ anavassavāya paṭipajjeyyātha.
pli-tv-pvr4:15.9.eng: If you don’t see such a root either in yourself or in others, you should practice so that it has no future effect.

pli-tv-pvr4:15.10.eng: In this way that bad root of disputes is abandoned.

pli-tv-pvr4:15.11.pli: Evametassa pāpakassa vivādamūlassa āyatiṃ anavassavo hoti.
pli-tv-pvr4:15.11.eng: In this way that bad root of disputes has no future effect.

pli-tv-pvr4:16.2.eng: (1) It may be that a monk is angry and resentful.

pli-tv-pvr4:16.7.pli: Yo hoti anuvādo bahujanāhitāya bahujanāsukhāya bahuno janassa anatthāya ahitāya dukkhāya devamanussānaṃ.

pli-tv-pvr4:18.1.eng: What are the six aspects of friendliness?

pli-tv-pvr4:18.2.pli: Idha bhikkhuno mettaṃ kāyakammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca.
pli-tv-pvr4:18.2.eng: (1) As to this, a monk acts with good will toward his fellow monastics, both in public and in private.

pli-tv-pvr4:18.3.pli: Ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṃvattati.

pli-tv-pvr4:19.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ bhikkhuno mettaṃ vacīkammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca.
pli-tv-pvr4:19.1.eng: (2) Furthermore, a monk speaks with good will to his fellow monastics, both in public and in private.

pli-tv-pvr4:19.2.pli: Ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṃvattati.

pli-tv-pvr4:20.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ bhikkhuno mettaṃ manokammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca.
pli-tv-pvr4:20.1.eng: (3) Furthermore, a monk thinks with good will about his fellow monastics, both in public and in private.

pli-tv-pvr4:20.2.pli: Ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṃvattati.

pli-tv-pvr4:21.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ bhikkhu ye te lābhā dhammikā dhammaladdhā antamaso pattapariyāpannamattampi tathārūpehi lābhehi appaṭivibhattabhogī hoti sīlavantehi sabrahmacārīhi sādhāraṇabhogī.
pli-tv-pvr4:21.1.eng: (4) Furthermore, whatever a monk has gained in an appropriate manner, even the content of his almsbowl, he shares without reservation with his virtuous fellow monastics.

pli-tv-pvr4:21.2.pli: Ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṃvattati.

pli-tv-pvr4:22.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ bhikkhu yāni tāni sīlāni akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni asabalāni akammāsāni bhujissāni viññupasatthāni aparāmaṭṭhāni samādhisaṃvattanikāni, tathārūpesu sīlesu sīlasāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca.
pli-tv-pvr4:22.1.eng: (5) Furthermore, a monk lives with his fellow monastics, both in public and in private, with moral conduct that is unbroken, consistent, spotless, pure, liberating, praised by the wise, ungrasped, and leading to stillness.

pli-tv-pvr4:22.2.pli: Ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṃvattati.

pli-tv-pvr4:23.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ bhikkhu yāyaṃ diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā diṭṭhisāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca.
pli-tv-pvr4:23.1.eng: (6) Furthermore, a monk lives with his fellow monastics, both in public and in private, with that noble view that is liberating and leads one who acts in accordance with it to the complete end of suffering.

pli-tv-pvr4:23.2.pli: Ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṃvattati.
pli-tv-pvr4:23.2.eng: These aspects of friendliness create love and respect, and lead to coming together, concord, harmony, and unity.

pli-tv-pvr4:24.1.eng: What are the eighteen grounds for schism?

pli-tv-pvr4:24.2.pli: Idha bhikkhu adhammaṃ “dhammo”ti dīpeti, dhammaṃ “adhammo”ti dīpeti, avinayaṃ “vinayo”ti dīpeti, vinayaṃ “avinayo”ti dīpeti, abhāsitaṃ alapitaṃ tathāgatena “bhāsitaṃ lapitaṃ tathāgatenā”ti dīpeti, bhāsitaṃ lapitaṃ tathāgatena “abhāsitaṃ alapitaṃ tathāgatenā”ti dīpeti, anāciṇṇaṃ tathāgatena “āciṇṇaṃ tathāgatenā”ti dīpeti, āciṇṇaṃ tathāgatena “anāciṇṇaṃ tathāgatenā”ti dīpeti, apaññattaṃ tathāgatena “paññattaṃ tathāgatenā”ti dīpeti, paññattaṃ tathāgatena “apaññattaṃ tathāgatenā”ti dīpeti, āpattiṃ “anāpattī”ti dīpeti, anāpattiṃ “āpattī”ti dīpeti, lahukaṃ āpattiṃ “garukā āpattī”ti dīpeti, garukaṃ āpattiṃ “lahukā āpattī”ti dīpeti, sāvasesaṃ āpattiṃ “anavasesā āpattī”ti dīpeti, anavasesaṃ āpattiṃ “sāvasesā āpattī”ti dīpeti, duṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ “aduṭṭhullā āpattī”ti dīpeti, aduṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ “duṭṭhullā āpattī”ti dīpeti.
pli-tv-pvr4:24.2.eng: In this case a monk proclaims what is contrary to the Teaching as being in accordance with it and what is in accordance with the Teaching as contrary to it. He proclaims what is contrary to the Monastic Law as being in accordance with it, and what is in accordance with the Monastic Law as contrary to it. He proclaims what hasn’t been spoken by the Buddha as spoken by him, and what has been spoken by the Buddha as not spoken by him. He proclaims what was not practiced by the Buddha as practiced by him, and what was practiced by the Buddha as not practiced by him. He proclaims what was not laid down by the Buddha as laid down by him, and what was laid down by the Buddha as not laid down by him. He proclaims a non-offense as an offense, and an offense as a non-offense. He proclaims a light offense as heavy, and a heavy offense as light. He proclaims a curable offense as incurable, and an incurable offense as curable. He proclaims a grave offense as minor, and a minor offense as grave.

pli-tv-pvr4:25.1.eng: What are the four kinds of legal issues?

pli-tv-pvr4:25.2.eng: Legal issues arising from disputes, legal issues arising from accusations, legal issues arising from offenses, legal issues arising from business.

pli-tv-pvr4:26.1.eng: What are the seven principles for settling them?

pli-tv-pvr4:26.2.pli: Sammukhāvinayo, sativinayo, amūḷhavinayo, paṭiññātakaraṇaṃ, yebhuyyasikā, tassapāpiyasikā, tiṇavatthārako—
pli-tv-pvr4:26.2.eng: Resolution face-to-face, resolution through recollection, resolution because of past insanity, acting according to what has been admitted, majority decision, further penalty, covering over as if with grass.

pli-tv-pvr4:27.1.eng: The section on questioning “how many?” is finished.

pli-tv-pvr4:31.0.eng: 1. The section on the six kinds of originations of offenses

pli-tv-pvr4:31.1.eng: “Is it possible to commit an offense entailing expulsion through the first kind of origination of offenses?”—

pli-tv-pvr4:32.1.eng: “Is it possible to commit an offense entailing expulsion through the second kind of origination of offenses?”—

pli-tv-pvr4:33.1.eng: “Is it possible to commit an offense entailing expulsion through the third kind of origination of offenses?”—

pli-tv-pvr4:34.1.eng: “Is it possible to commit an offense entailing expulsion through the fourth kind of origination of offenses?”—

pli-tv-pvr4:35.1.eng: “Is it possible to commit an offense entailing expulsion through the fifth kind of origination of offenses?”—

pli-tv-pvr4:36.1.eng: “Is it possible to commit an offense entailing expulsion through the sixth kind of origination of offenses?”—

pli-tv-pvr4:37.1.eng: The first section on the six kinds of originations of offenses is finished.

pli-tv-pvr4:38.0.eng: 2. The section on “how many kinds of offenses?”

pli-tv-pvr4:38.1.eng: “How many kinds of offenses does one commit through the first kind of origination of offenses?

pli-tv-pvr4:38.3.pli: Bhikkhu kappiyasaññī saññācikāya kuṭiṃ karoti adesitavatthukaṃ pamāṇātikkantaṃ sārambhaṃ aparikkamanaṃ, payoge dukkaṭaṃ;
pli-tv-pvr4:38.3.eng: (1) when a monk—perceiving it as allowable and by means of begging—builds a hut whose site has not been approved, which exceeds the right size, where harm will be done, and which lacks a space on all sides, then for the effort there is an offense of wrong conduct;

pli-tv-pvr4:38.4.eng: (2) when there is one piece left to complete the hut, he commits a serious offense;

pli-tv-pvr4:38.5.eng: (3) when the last piece is finished, he commits an offense entailing suspension;

pli-tv-pvr4:38.6.pli: bhikkhu kappiyasaññī vikāle bhojanaṃ bhuñjati, āpatti pācittiyassa;
pli-tv-pvr4:38.6.eng: (4) when a monk, perceiving it as allowable, eats cooked food at the wrong time, he commits an offense entailing confession;

pli-tv-pvr4:38.7.pli: bhikkhu kappiyasaññī aññātikāya bhikkhuniyā antaragharaṃ paviṭṭhāya hatthato khādanīyaṃ vā bhojanīyaṃ vā sahatthā paṭiggahetvā bhuñjati, āpatti pāṭidesanīyassa—
pli-tv-pvr4:38.7.eng: (5) when a monk, perceiving it as allowable, receives fresh or cooked food directly from an unrelated nun who has entered an inhabited area, and then eats it, he commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.

pli-tv-pvr4:38.8.pli: paṭhamena āpattisamuṭṭhānena imā pañca āpattiyo āpajjati.

pli-tv-pvr4:39.1.pli: Tā āpattiyo catunnaṃ vipattīnaṃ kati vipattiyo bhajanti?
pli-tv-pvr4:39.1.eng: When it comes to these offenses, to how many of the four kinds of failure do they belong?

pli-tv-pvr4:39.2.eng: In how many of the seven classes of offenses are they found?

pli-tv-pvr4:39.3.eng: Through how many of the six kinds of originations of offenses do they originate?

pli-tv-pvr4:39.4.eng: To which of the four kinds of legal issues do they belong?

pli-tv-pvr4:39.5.eng: Through how many of the seven principles for settling legal issues are they settled?

pli-tv-pvr4:39.6.pli: Tā āpattiyo catunnaṃ vipattīnaṃ dve vipattiyo bhajanti—
pli-tv-pvr4:39.6.eng: They belong to two kinds of failure:

pli-tv-pvr4:39.7.eng: they may be failure in morality; they may be failure in conduct.

pli-tv-pvr4:39.8.eng: They are found in five classes of offenses:

pli-tv-pvr4:39.9.pli: siyā saṅghādisesāpattikkhandhena, siyā thullaccayāpattikkhandhena, siyā pācittiyāpattikkhandhena, siyā pāṭidesanīyāpattikkhandhena, siyā dukkaṭāpattikkhandhena.
pli-tv-pvr4:39.9.eng: they may be in the class of offenses entailing suspension; they may be in the class of serious offenses; they may be in the class of offenses entailing confession; they may be in the class of offenses entailing acknowledgment; they may be in the class of offenses of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-pvr4:39.11.pli: kāyato samuṭṭhanti, na vācato na cittato.
pli-tv-pvr4:39.11.eng: from body, not from speech or mind.

pli-tv-pvr4:39.12.eng: They belong to legal issues arising from offenses.

pli-tv-pvr4:39.13.eng: They are settled through three principles:

pli-tv-pvr4:39.14.pli: siyā sammukhāvinayena ca paṭiññātakaraṇena ca, siyā sammukhāvinayena ca tiṇavatthārakena ca.
pli-tv-pvr4:39.14.eng: they may be settled by resolution face-to-face and by acting according to what has been admitted; or they may be settled by resolution face-to-face and by covering over as if with grass.

pli-tv-pvr4:40.1.eng: How many kinds of offenses does one commit through the second kind of origination of offenses?

pli-tv-pvr4:40.3.pli: bhikkhu kappiyasaññī samādisati—“kuṭiṃ me karothā”ti. Tassa kuṭiṃ karonti adesitavatthukaṃ pamāṇātikkantaṃ sārambhaṃ aparikkamanaṃ. Payoge dukkaṭaṃ;
pli-tv-pvr4:40.3.eng: (1) when a monk, perceiving it as allowable, appoints someone to build him a hut, and they build a hut whose site has not been approved, which exceeds the right size, where harm will be done, and which lacks a space on all sides, then for the effort there is an offense of wrong conduct;

pli-tv-pvr4:40.4.eng: (2) when there is one piece left to complete the hut, he commits a serious offense;

pli-tv-pvr4:40.5.eng: (3) when the last piece is finished, he commits an offense entailing suspension;

pli-tv-pvr4:40.6.pli: Bhikkhu kappiyasaññī anupasampannaṃ padaso dhammaṃ vāceti, āpatti pācittiyassa—
pli-tv-pvr4:40.6.eng: (4) when a monk, perceiving it as allowable, instructs a person who is not fully ordained to memorize the Teaching, he commits an offense entailing confession.

pli-tv-pvr4:40.7.pli: dutiyena āpattisamuṭṭhānena imā catasso āpattiyo āpajjati.

pli-tv-pvr4:41.11.pli: siyā sammukhāvinayena ca paṭiññātakaraṇena ca, siyā sammukhāvinayena ca tiṇavatthārakena ca.

pli-tv-pvr4:42.3.pli: Bhikkhu kappiyasaññī saṃvidahitvā kuṭiṃ karoti adesitavatthukaṃ pamāṇātikkantaṃ sārambhaṃ aparikkamanaṃ. Payoge dukkaṭaṃ;
pli-tv-pvr4:42.3.eng: (1) when a monk—perceiving it as allowable and having appointed someone—builds a hut whose site has not been approved, which exceeds the right size, where harm will be done, and which lacks a space on all sides, then for the effort there is an offense of wrong conduct;
pli-tv-pvr4:42.3.comm: The Pali reads saṁvidahitvā, whereas the text at Bu Ss 6:3.5.1 reads samādisati. Presumably this is only for grammatical reasons.

pli-tv-pvr4:42.4.eng: (2) when there is one piece left to complete the hut, he commits a serious offense;

pli-tv-pvr4:42.5.eng: (3) when the last piece is finished, he commits an offense entailing suspension;

pli-tv-pvr4:42.6.pli: Bhikkhu kappiyasaññī paṇītabhojanāni attano atthāya viññāpetvā bhuñjati, āpatti pācittiyassa.
pli-tv-pvr4:42.6.eng: (4) when a monk, perceiving it as allowable, eats fine foods that he has requested for himself, he commits an offense entailing confession;

pli-tv-pvr4:42.7.pli: Bhikkhu kappiyasaññī bhikkhuniyā vosāsantiyā na nivāretvā bhuñjati, āpatti pāṭidesanīyassa—
pli-tv-pvr4:42.7.eng: (5) when a monk, perceiving it as allowable, eats without having restrained a nun who is giving directions, he commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.

pli-tv-pvr4:42.8.pli: tatiyena āpattisamuṭṭhānena imā pañca āpattiyo āpajjati.

pli-tv-pvr4:43.11.pli: siyā sammukhāvinayena ca paṭiññātakaraṇena ca, siyā sammukhāvinayena ca tiṇavatthārakena ca.

pli-tv-pvr4:44.1.eng: How many kinds of offenses does one commit through the fourth kind of origination of offenses?

pli-tv-pvr4:44.3.pli: bhikkhu methunaṃ dhammaṃ paṭisevati, āpatti pārājikassa;
pli-tv-pvr4:44.3.eng: (1) when a monk has sexual intercourse, he commits an offense entailing expulsion;

pli-tv-pvr4:44.4.pli: bhikkhu akappiyasaññī saññācikāya kuṭiṃ karoti adesitavatthukaṃ pamāṇātikkantaṃ sārambhaṃ aparikkamanaṃ, payoge dukkaṭaṃ;
pli-tv-pvr4:44.4.eng: (2) when a monk—perceiving it as unallowable and by means of begging—builds a hut whose site has not been approved, which exceeds the right size, where harm will be done, and which lacks a space on all sides, then for the effort there is an offense of wrong conduct;

pli-tv-pvr4:44.5.eng: (3) when there is one piece left to complete the hut, he commits a serious offense;

pli-tv-pvr4:44.6.eng: (4) when the last piece is finished, he commits an offense entailing suspension;

pli-tv-pvr4:44.7.pli: Bhikkhu akappiyasaññī vikāle bhojanaṃ bhuñjati, āpatti pācittiyassa.
pli-tv-pvr4:44.7.eng: (5) when a monk, perceiving it as unallowable, eats cooked food at the wrong time, he commits an offense entailing confession;

pli-tv-pvr4:44.8.pli: Bhikkhu akappiyasaññī aññātikāya bhikkhuniyā antaragharaṃ paviṭṭhāya hatthato khādanīyaṃ vā bhojanīyaṃ vā sahatthā paṭiggahetvā bhuñjati, āpatti pāṭidesanīyassa.
pli-tv-pvr4:44.8.eng: (6) when a monk, perceiving it as unallowable, receives fresh or cooked food directly from an unrelated nun who has entered an inhabited area, and then eats it, he commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.

pli-tv-pvr4:44.9.pli: Catutthena āpattisamuṭṭhānena imā cha āpattiyo āpajjati.

pli-tv-pvr4:46.1.eng: How many kinds of offenses does one commit through the fifth kind of origination of offenses?

pli-tv-pvr4:46.3.pli: Bhikkhu pāpiccho icchāpakato asantaṃ abhūtaṃ uttarimanussadhammaṃ ullapati, āpatti pārājikassa;
pli-tv-pvr4:46.3.eng: (1) when a monk, having bad desires, overcome by desire, claims a non-existent superhuman quality, he commits an offense entailing expulsion;

pli-tv-pvr4:46.4.pli: bhikkhu akappiyasaññī samādisati—“kuṭiṃ me karothā”ti. Tassa kuṭiṃ karonti adesitavatthukaṃ pamāṇātikkantaṃ sārambhaṃ aparikkamanaṃ. Payoge dukkaṭaṃ;
pli-tv-pvr4:46.4.eng: (2) when a monk, perceiving it as unallowable, appoints someone to build him a hut, and they build a hut whose site has not been approved, which exceeds the right size, where harm will be done, and which lacks a space on all sides, then for the effort there is an offense of wrong conduct;

pli-tv-pvr4:46.5.eng: (3) when there is one piece left to complete the hut, he commits a serious offense;

pli-tv-pvr4:46.6.eng: (4) when the last piece is finished, he commits an offense entailing suspension;

pli-tv-pvr4:46.7.pli: Bhikkhu akappiyasaññī anupasampannaṃ padaso dhammaṃ vāceti, āpatti pācittiyassa.
pli-tv-pvr4:46.7.eng: (5) when a monk, perceiving it as unallowable, instructs a person who is not fully ordained to memorize the Teaching, he commits an offense entailing confession;

pli-tv-pvr4:46.8.pli: Na khuṃsetukāmo na vambhetukāmo na maṅkukattukāmo davakamyatā hīnena hīnaṃ vadeti, āpatti dubbhāsitassa—
pli-tv-pvr4:46.8.eng: (6) when—not wishing to revile, not wishing to insult, not wishing to humiliate, but wanting to have fun—one says what is low to one who is low, one commits an offense of wrong speech.

pli-tv-pvr4:46.9.pli: pañcamena āpattisamuṭṭhānena imā cha āpattiyo āpajjati.

pli-tv-pvr4:48.3.pli: bhikkhu saṃvidahitvā bhaṇḍaṃ avaharati, āpatti pārājikassa;
pli-tv-pvr4:48.3.eng: (1) when a monk, having agreed with others, steals goods, he commits an offense entailing expulsion;

pli-tv-pvr4:48.6.eng: (4) when the last piece is finished, he commits an offense entailing suspension;

pli-tv-pvr4:48.7.pli: Bhikkhu akappiyasaññī paṇītabhojanāni attano atthāya viññāpetvā bhuñjati, āpatti pācittiyassa.

pli-tv-pvr4:48.8.eng: (6) when a monk, perceiving it as unallowable, eats without having restrained a nun who is giving directions, he commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.

pli-tv-pvr4:48.9.pli: chaṭṭhena āpattisamuṭṭhānena imā cha āpattiyo āpajjati.

pli-tv-pvr4:49.1.eng: When it comes to these offenses, to how many of the four kinds of failure do they belong?

pli-tv-pvr4:49.2.eng: In how many of the seven classes of offenses are they found?

pli-tv-pvr4:49.5.eng: Through how many of the seven principles for settling legal issues are they settled?

pli-tv-pvr4:49.6.eng: They belong to two kinds of failure:

pli-tv-pvr4:49.7.eng: they may be failure in morality; they may be failure in conduct.

pli-tv-pvr4:49.8.eng: They are found in six classes of offenses:

pli-tv-pvr4:49.9.pli: siyā pārājikāpattikkhandhena, siyā saṅghādisesāpattikkhandhena, siyā thullaccayāpattikkhandhena, siyā pācittiyāpattikkhandhena, siyā pāṭidesanīyāpattikkhandhena, siyā dukkaṭāpattikkhandhena.
pli-tv-pvr4:49.9.eng: they may be in the class of offenses entailing expulsion; they may be in the class of offenses entailing suspension; they may be in the class of serious offenses; they may be in the class of offenses entailing confession; they may be in the class of offenses entailing acknowledgment; they may be in the class of offenses of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-pvr4:49.11.pli: kāyato ca vācato ca cittato ca samuṭṭhanti.

pli-tv-pvr4:49.12.eng: They belong to legal issues arising from offenses.

pli-tv-pvr4:49.13.eng: They are settled through three principles:

pli-tv-pvr4:49.14.pli: siyā sammukhāvinayena ca paṭiññātakaraṇena ca, siyā sammukhāvinayena ca tiṇavatthārakena cāti.
pli-tv-pvr4:49.14.eng: they may be settled by resolution face-to-face and by acting according to what has been admitted; or they may be settled by resolution face-to-face and by covering over as if with grass.”

pli-tv-pvr4:50.1.eng: The second section on “how many kinds of offenses?” for the six kinds of originations of offenses is finished.

pli-tv-pvr4:51.0.eng: 3. The verses on the kinds of originations of offenses

pli-tv-pvr4:51.1.eng: “Origination from body has been declared by the one who benefits the world,

pli-tv-pvr4:51.2.eng: The one of boundless vision, seeing seclusion:

pli-tv-pvr4:51.3.eng: I ask how many kinds of offenses originate from that—

pli-tv-pvr4:51.4.eng: You who are skilled in analysis, please say.

pli-tv-pvr4:52.2.eng: The one of boundless vision, seeing seclusion:

pli-tv-pvr4:52.3.eng: Five kinds of offenses originate from that—

pli-tv-pvr4:52.4.eng: I declare this to you, you who are skilled in analysis.

pli-tv-pvr4:63.1.eng: The third section on the verses on the kinds of originations of offenses is finished.

pli-tv-pvr4:64.0.eng: 4. The section on “as a result of failure”

pli-tv-pvr4:64.1.eng: How many kinds of offenses does one commit as a result of failure in morality?

pli-tv-pvr4:64.3.pli: bhikkhunī jānaṃ pārājikaṃ dhammaṃ paṭicchādeti, āpatti pārājikassa;
pli-tv-pvr4:64.3.eng: when a nun knowingly conceals an offense entailing expulsion, she commits an offense entailing expulsion;

pli-tv-pvr4:64.4.eng: when, being unsure, she conceals it, she commits a serious offense;

pli-tv-pvr4:64.5.eng: when a monk conceals an offense entailing suspension, he commits an offense entailing confession;

pli-tv-pvr4:64.6.pli: attano duṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ paṭicchādeti, āpatti dukkaṭassa—
pli-tv-pvr4:64.6.eng: when he conceals a grave offense of his own, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-pvr4:65.1.pli: Tā āpattiyo catunnaṃ vipattīnaṃ kati vipattiyo bhajanti …pe…
pli-tv-pvr4:65.1.eng: When it comes to these offenses, to how many of the four kinds of failure do they belong? …

pli-tv-pvr4:65.2.eng: Through how many of the seven principles for settling legal issues are they settled?

pli-tv-pvr4:65.3.pli: Tā āpattiyo catunnaṃ vipattīnaṃ dve vipattiyo bhajanti—
pli-tv-pvr4:65.3.eng: They belong to two kinds of failure:

pli-tv-pvr4:65.4.eng: they may be failure in morality; they may be failure in conduct.

pli-tv-pvr4:65.5.eng: They are found in four classes of offenses:

pli-tv-pvr4:65.6.pli: siyā pārājikāpattikkhandhena, siyā thullaccayāpattikkhandhena, siyā pācittiyāpattikkhandhena, siyā dukkaṭāpattikkhandhena.
pli-tv-pvr4:65.6.eng: they may be in the class of offenses entailing expulsion; they may be in the class of serious offenses; they may be in the class of offenses entailing confession; they may be in the class of offenses of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-pvr4:65.8.pli: kāyato ca vācato ca cittato ca samuṭṭhanti.

pli-tv-pvr4:65.9.eng: They belong to legal issues arising from offenses.

pli-tv-pvr4:65.10.eng: They are settled through three principles:

pli-tv-pvr4:65.11.pli: siyā sammukhāvinayena ca paṭiññātakaraṇena ca, siyā sammukhāvinayena ca tiṇavatthārakena ca.
pli-tv-pvr4:65.11.eng: they may be settled by resolution face-to-face and by acting according to what has been admitted; or they may be settled by resolution face-to-face and by covering over as if with grass.

pli-tv-pvr4:66.1.eng: How many kinds of offenses does one commit as a result of failure in conduct?

pli-tv-pvr4:66.3.eng: when one conceals a failure in conduct, one commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-pvr4:67.1.pli: Sā āpatti catunnaṃ vipattīnaṃ kati vipattiyo bhajati …pe…
pli-tv-pvr4:67.1.eng: When it comes to this offense, to how many of the four kinds of failure does it belong? …

pli-tv-pvr4:67.2.eng: Through how many of the seven principles for settling legal issues is it settled?

pli-tv-pvr4:67.3.pli: Sā āpatti catunnaṃ vipattīnaṃ ekaṃ vipattiṃ bhajati—
pli-tv-pvr4:67.3.eng: It belongs to one kind of failure:

pli-tv-pvr4:67.5.eng: It is found in one class of offenses:

pli-tv-pvr4:67.6.eng: in the class of offenses of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-pvr4:67.8.pli: kāyato ca vācato ca cittato ca samuṭṭhāti.

pli-tv-pvr4:67.9.eng: It belongs to legal issues arising from offenses.

pli-tv-pvr4:67.10.eng: They are settled through three principles:

pli-tv-pvr4:67.11.pli: siyā sammukhāvinayena ca paṭiññātakaraṇena ca, siyā sammukhāvinayena ca tiṇavatthārakena ca.
pli-tv-pvr4:67.11.eng: they may be settled by resolution face-to-face and by acting according to what has been admitted; or they may be settled by resolution face-to-face and by covering over as if with grass.

pli-tv-pvr4:68.1.eng: How many kinds of offenses does one commit as a result of failure in view?

pli-tv-pvr4:68.3.pli: Pāpikāya diṭṭhiyā yāvatatiyaṃ samanubhāsanāya na paṭinissajjati, ñattiyā dukkaṭaṃ;
pli-tv-pvr4:68.3.eng: when not giving up a bad view after being pressed for the third time, then after the motion, one commits an offense of wrong conduct;

pli-tv-pvr4:68.4.eng: when the last announcement is finished, one commits an offense entailing confession.

pli-tv-pvr4:69.1.pli: Tā āpattiyo catunnaṃ vipattīnaṃ kati vipattiyo bhajanti …pe…
pli-tv-pvr4:69.1.eng: When it comes to these offenses, to how many of the four kinds of failure do they belong? …

pli-tv-pvr4:69.2.eng: Through how many of the seven principles for settling legal issues are they settled?

pli-tv-pvr4:69.3.pli: Tā āpattiyo catunnaṃ vipattīnaṃ ekaṃ vipattiṃ bhajanti—
pli-tv-pvr4:69.3.eng: They belong to one kind of failure:

pli-tv-pvr4:69.5.eng: They are found in two classes of offenses:

pli-tv-pvr4:69.6.eng: they may be in the class of offenses entailing confession; they may be in the class of offenses of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-pvr4:69.8.pli: kāyato ca vācato ca cittato ca samuṭṭhanti.

pli-tv-pvr4:69.9.eng: They belong to legal issues arising from offenses.

pli-tv-pvr4:69.10.eng: They are settled through three principles:

pli-tv-pvr4:69.11.pli: siyā sammukhāvinayena ca paṭiññātakaraṇena ca, siyā sammukhāvinayena ca tiṇavatthārakena ca.
pli-tv-pvr4:69.11.eng: they may be settled by resolution face-to-face and by acting according to what has been admitted; or they may be settled by resolution face-to-face and by covering over as if with grass.

pli-tv-pvr4:70.1.eng: How many kinds of offenses does one commit as a result of failure in livelihood?

pli-tv-pvr4:70.3.pli: ājīvahetu ājīvakāraṇā pāpiccho icchāpakato asantaṃ abhūtaṃ uttarimanussadhammaṃ ullapati, āpatti pārājikassa;
pli-tv-pvr4:70.3.eng: (1) when, to make a living, having bad desires, overcome by desire, one claims a non-existent superhuman quality, one commits an offense entailing expulsion;

pli-tv-pvr4:70.4.pli: ājīvahetu ājīvakāraṇā sañcarittaṃ samāpajjati, āpatti saṅghādisesassa;
pli-tv-pvr4:70.4.eng: (2) when, to make a living, one acts as a matchmaker, one commits an offense entailing suspension;

pli-tv-pvr4:70.5.pli: ājīvahetu ājīvakāraṇā “yo te vihāre vasati, so bhikkhu arahā”ti bhaṇati, paṭivijānantassa āpatti thullaccayassa;
pli-tv-pvr4:70.5.eng: (3) when, to make a living, one says, “The monk who stays in your dwelling is a perfected one,” and the listener understands, one commits a serious offense;

pli-tv-pvr4:70.6.pli: ājīvahetu ājīvakāraṇā bhikkhu paṇītabhojanāni attano atthāya viññāpetvā bhuñjati, āpatti pācittiyassa;
pli-tv-pvr4:70.6.eng: (4) when, to make a living, a monk eats fine foods that he has requested for himself, he commits an offense entailing confession;

pli-tv-pvr4:70.7.pli: ājīvahetu ājīvakāraṇā bhikkhunī paṇītabhojanāni attano atthāya viññāpetvā bhuñjati, āpatti pāṭidesanīyassa;
pli-tv-pvr4:70.7.eng: (5) when, to make a living, a nun eats fine foods that she has requested for herself, she commits an offense entailing acknowledgment;

pli-tv-pvr4:70.8.pli: ājīvahetu ājīvakāraṇā sūpaṃ vā odanaṃ vā agilāno attano atthāya viññāpetvā bhuñjati, āpatti dukkaṭassa—
pli-tv-pvr4:70.8.eng: (6) when, to make a living, one eats bean curry or rice that one has requested for oneself, one commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-pvr4:71.1.pli: Tā āpattiyo catunnaṃ vipattīnaṃ kati vipattiyo bhajanti …pe…
pli-tv-pvr4:71.1.eng: When it comes to these offenses, to how many of the four kinds of failure do they belong? …

pli-tv-pvr4:71.2.eng: Through how many of the seven principles for settling legal issues are they settled?

pli-tv-pvr4:71.3.pli: Tā āpattiyo catunnaṃ vipattīnaṃ dve vipattiyo bhajanti—
pli-tv-pvr4:71.3.eng: They belong to two kinds of failure:

pli-tv-pvr4:71.4.eng: they may be failure in morality; they may be failure in conduct.

pli-tv-pvr4:71.5.eng: They are found in six classes of offenses:

pli-tv-pvr4:71.6.pli: siyā pārājikāpattikkhandhena, siyā saṅghādisesāpattikkhandhena, siyā thullaccayāpattikkhandhena, siyā pācittiyāpattikkhandhena, siyā pāṭidesanīyāpattikkhandhena, siyā dukkaṭāpattikkhandhena.
pli-tv-pvr4:71.6.eng: they may be in the class of offenses entailing expulsion; they may be in the class of offenses entailing suspension; they may be in the class of serious offenses; they may be in the class of offenses entailing confession; they may be in the class of offenses entailing acknowledgment; they may be in the class of offenses of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-pvr4:71.8.pli: siyā kāyato samuṭṭhanti, na vācato na cittato;
pli-tv-pvr4:71.8.eng: from body, not from speech or mind; or

pli-tv-pvr4:71.9.pli: siyā vācato samuṭṭhanti, na kāyato na cittato;
pli-tv-pvr4:71.9.eng: from speech, not from body or mind; or

pli-tv-pvr4:71.10.pli: siyā kāyato ca vācato ca samuṭṭhanti, na cittato;
pli-tv-pvr4:71.10.eng: from body and speech, not from mind; or

pli-tv-pvr4:71.11.pli: siyā kāyato ca cittato ca samuṭṭhanti, na vācato;
pli-tv-pvr4:71.11.eng: from body and mind, not from speech; or

pli-tv-pvr4:71.12.pli: siyā vācato ca cittato ca samuṭṭhanti, na kāyato;
pli-tv-pvr4:71.12.eng: from speech and mind, not from body; or

pli-tv-pvr4:71.13.pli: siyā kāyato ca vācato ca cittato ca samuṭṭhanti.

pli-tv-pvr4:71.14.eng: They belong to legal issues arising from offenses.

pli-tv-pvr4:71.15.eng: They are settled through three principles:

pli-tv-pvr4:71.16.pli: siyā sammukhāvinayena ca paṭiññātakaraṇena ca, siyā sammukhāvinayena ca tiṇavatthārakena ca.
pli-tv-pvr4:71.16.eng: they may be settled by resolution face-to-face and by acting according to what has been admitted; or they may be settled by resolution face-to-face and by covering over as if with grass.

pli-tv-pvr4:72.1.eng: The fourth section on “as a result of failure” is finished.

pli-tv-pvr4:73.0.eng: 5. The section on “as a result of legal issues”

pli-tv-pvr4:73.1.eng: “How many kinds of offenses does one commit as a result of legal issues arising from disputes?

pli-tv-pvr4:73.3.eng: when one speaks abusively to one who is fully ordained, one commits an offense entailing confession;

pli-tv-pvr4:73.4.eng: when one speaks abusively to one who is not fully ordained, one commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-pvr4:74.13.eng: they may be settled by resolution face-to-face and by acting according to what has been admitted; or they may be settled by resolution face-to-face and by covering over as if with grass.

pli-tv-pvr4:75.1.eng: How many kinds of offenses does one commit as a result of legal issues arising from accusations?

pli-tv-pvr4:75.3.pli: Bhikkhuṃ amūlakena pārājikena dhammena anuddhaṃseti, āpatti saṅghādisesassa;
pli-tv-pvr4:75.3.eng: when one groundlessly charges a monk with an offense entailing expulsion, one commits an offense entailing suspension;

pli-tv-pvr4:75.4.eng: when one groundlessly charges him with an offense entailing suspension, one commits an offense entailing confession;

pli-tv-pvr4:75.5.eng: when one groundlessly charges him with failure in conduct, one commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-pvr4:78.4.eng: they may be failure in morality; they may be failure in conduct.

pli-tv-pvr4:78.5.eng: They are found in four classes of offenses:

pli-tv-pvr4:78.6.pli: siyā pārājikāpattikkhandhena, siyā thullaccayāpattikkhandhena, siyā pācittiyāpattikkhandhena, siyā dukkaṭāpattikkhandhena.
pli-tv-pvr4:78.6.eng: they may be in the class of offenses entailing expulsion; they may be in the class of serious offenses; they may be in the class of offenses entailing confession; they may be in the class of offenses of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-pvr4:78.8.pli: kāyato ca vācato ca cittato ca samuṭṭhanti.

pli-tv-pvr4:78.9.eng: They belong to legal issues arising from offenses.

pli-tv-pvr4:78.10.eng: They are settled through three principles:

pli-tv-pvr4:78.11.pli: siyā sammukhāvinayena ca paṭiññātakaraṇena ca, siyā sammukhāvinayena ca tiṇavatthārakena ca.
pli-tv-pvr4:78.11.eng: they may be settled by resolution face-to-face and by acting according to what has been admitted; or they may be settled by resolution face-to-face and by covering over as if with grass.

pli-tv-pvr4:79.1.eng: How many kinds of offenses does one commit as a result of legal issues arising from business?

pli-tv-pvr4:79.3.pli: Ukkhittānuvattikā bhikkhunī yāvatatiyaṃ samanubhāsanāya na paṭinissajjati, ñattiyā dukkaṭaṃ;
pli-tv-pvr4:79.3.eng: (1) when a nun takes sides with one who has been ejected and does not stop when pressed for the third time, then after the motion, she commits an offense of wrong conduct;

pli-tv-pvr4:79.4.eng: (2) after each of the first two announcements, she commits a serious offense;

pli-tv-pvr4:79.5.eng: (3) when the last announcement is finished, she commits an offense entailing expulsion;

pli-tv-pvr4:79.6.pli: Bhedakānuvattakā bhikkhū yāvatatiyaṃ samanubhāsanāya na paṭinissajjanti, āpatti saṅghādisesassa;
pli-tv-pvr4:79.6.eng: (4) when monks who side with a monk who is pursuing schism do not stop when pressed for the third time, they commit an offense entailing suspension;

pli-tv-pvr4:79.7.pli: pāpikāya diṭṭhiyā yāvatatiyaṃ samanubhāsanāya na paṭinissajjati, āpatti pācittiyassa—
pli-tv-pvr4:79.7.eng: (5) when not giving up a bad view after being pressed for the third time, one commits an offense entailing confession.

pli-tv-pvr4:80.1.pli: Tā āpattiyo catunnaṃ vipattīnaṃ kati vipattiyo bhajanti …pe…
pli-tv-pvr4:80.1.eng: When it comes to these offenses, to how many of the four kinds of failure do they belong? …

pli-tv-pvr4:80.2.eng: Through how many of the seven principles for settling legal issues are they settled?

pli-tv-pvr4:80.3.pli: Tā āpattiyo catunnaṃ vipattīnaṃ dve vipattiyo bhajanti—
pli-tv-pvr4:80.3.eng: They belong to two kinds of failure:

pli-tv-pvr4:80.4.eng: they may be failure in morality; they may be failure in conduct.

pli-tv-pvr4:80.5.eng: They are found in five classes of offenses:

pli-tv-pvr4:80.6.pli: siyā pārājikāpattikkhandhena, siyā saṅghādisesāpattikkhandhena, siyā thullaccayāpattikkhandhena, siyā pācittiyāpattikkhandhena, siyā dukkaṭāpattikkhandhena.
pli-tv-pvr4:80.6.eng: they may be in the class of offenses entailing expulsion; they may be in the class of offenses entailing suspension; they may be in the class of serious offenses; they may be in the class of offenses entailing confession; they may be in the class of offenses of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-pvr4:80.8.pli: kāyato ca vācato ca cittato ca samuṭṭhanti.

pli-tv-pvr4:80.9.eng: They belong to legal issues arising from offenses.

pli-tv-pvr4:80.10.eng: They are settled through three principles:

pli-tv-pvr4:80.11.pli: siyā sammukhāvinayena ca paṭiññātakaraṇena ca, siyā sammukhāvinayena ca tiṇavatthārakena ca.
pli-tv-pvr4:80.11.eng: they may be settled by resolution face-to-face and by acting according to what has been admitted; or they may be settled by resolution face-to-face and by covering over as if with grass.

pli-tv-pvr4:81.1.pli: Ṭhapetvā satta āpattiyo satta āpattikkhandhe, avasesā āpattiyo catunnaṃ vipattīnaṃ kati vipattiyo bhajanti?
pli-tv-pvr4:81.1.eng: Apart from the seven kinds of offenses and the seven classes of offenses, when it comes to the rest of the offenses, to how many of the four kinds of failure do they belong?

pli-tv-pvr4:81.2.eng: In how many of the seven classes of offenses are they found?

pli-tv-pvr4:81.3.eng: Through how many of the six kinds of originations of offenses do they originate?

pli-tv-pvr4:81.4.eng: To which of the four kinds of legal issues do they belong?

pli-tv-pvr4:81.5.eng: Through how many of the seven principles for settling legal issues are they settled?

pli-tv-pvr4:81.6.pli: Ṭhapetvā satta āpattiyo satta āpattikkhandhe avasesā āpattiyo catunnaṃ vipattīnaṃ na katamaṃ vipattiṃ bhajanti?
pli-tv-pvr4:81.6.eng: Apart from the seven kinds of offenses and the seven classes of offenses, the rest of the offenses do not belong to any of the four kinds of failure.

pli-tv-pvr4:81.7.pli: Sattannaṃ āpattikkhandhānaṃ na katamena āpattikkhandhena saṅgahitā.
pli-tv-pvr4:81.7.eng: They are not found in any of the seven classes of offenses.

pli-tv-pvr4:81.8.pli: Channaṃ āpattisamuṭṭhānānaṃ na katamena āpattisamuṭṭhānena samuṭṭhanti.
pli-tv-pvr4:81.8.eng: They do not originate through any of the six kinds of originations of offenses.

pli-tv-pvr4:81.9.eng: They do not belong to any of the four kinds of legal issues.

pli-tv-pvr4:81.10.pli: Sattannaṃ samathānaṃ na katamena samathena sammanti.
pli-tv-pvr4:81.10.eng: They are not settled through any of the seven principles for settling legal issues.

pli-tv-pvr4:81.12.pli: Ṭhapetvā satta āpattiyo satta āpattikkhandhe, natthaññā āpattiyoti.
pli-tv-pvr4:81.12.eng: Apart from the seven kinds of offenses and the seven classes of offenses, there are no other offenses.”

pli-tv-pvr4:82.1.eng: The fifth section on “as a result of legal issues” is finished.

pli-tv-pvr4:83.1.eng: More on the origination of offenses is finished.

pli-tv-pvr4:85.2.eng: And so ‘how many kinds of offenses?’
